subtitle: Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is psychoactive drugs.
My guest is the legendary Dennis McKenna.
He is the founding board member of the Hefner Research Institute.
He is the director and president of McKenna Academy of Natural Philosophy.
With his brother Terrence McKenna, he is author
of or co-author of The Invisible Landscape
Mind, Hallucinogens in the I Ching.
They also co-authored under pen names the
book Psilocybin, The Magic Mushroom Grower's
Guide.
Since Terrence's unfortunate death many years
ago, I believe it was the year 2000, Dennis
has written Brotherhood of the Screaming Abyss, My Life with Terrence McKenna.
More recently he has edited a two-volume ethno-pharmacologic
search for psychoactive drugs, which is the
record of two conferences held 50 years apart in 1967 and in the year 2017.
Dennis is located in British Columbia.
And now I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome Dennis, it's a pleasure to be with you.
Very much a pleasure to be here Jeffrey, thank you for asking me.
It's a special experience for me having many
years ago conducted several interviews with
your brother Terrence there among the most popular interviews we've ever released.
But I know you've always been in the background
of his story and as I read over your book
The Brotherhood of the Screaming Abyss, I can
see that many times you were in the foreground.
In some ways, I mean I was in the background
by preference, but yes, I mean Terrence had
a silver tongue and he was an excellent conversationalist
and deeply steeped in philosophy and widely
read.
I'm not nearly as erudite as he is, but and
his things, his talks have enormous longevity.
I imagine those talks were like in the late
80s, early 90s that you did with him and people
are still listening to them.
I mean he's amazing, he's achieved this strange virtual form of immortality.
His work is all over the YouTube, all over the net.
He has more followers on Twitter than I do,
I mean he's been dead for 22 years, not bad.
That's a slight exaggeration, but anyway he's
still very timely and I think in part it's
because his talks were so out of time, they were so ahead of their time in some ways.
So yeah, it's a high bar, Jeffrey, but we'll do our best here.
I am delighted to have this time with you.
I know your recent book, The Ethnopharmacologic
View of Psychoactive Drugs was based on a
couple of conferences, one back in 1967, one
in 2017 and I think it's worth mentioning
that I had the opportunity to meet you in person just a few months ago in 2022 at yet
another conference on the impact of drugs and that conference was of special interest
to me because it related to the idea that the spirit entities that people seem to be
in communication with under the influence of DMT in particular might be real.
That was a fascinating conference and when this
topic comes up about these sentient entities,
whatever they may be, of course immediately the question becomes, are they real?
And then the question becomes, what do you mean by real?
I mean I sort of start from the premise that anything you experience is real.
That doesn't mean that it's necessarily outside
your head or that you get into these conversations
about inside and outside and real and not real.
One thing that psychedelic experiences teach you
I think is that these are very fluid concepts.
You take psychedelics and often one of the take-home lessons, one of the major ones is
that everything is connected, we are all one, that kind of thing.
Interestingly earlier today I was just reading
my news feed and there was a talk, there was
an article I think it was in, now I don't remember what it was in, I think it was in
The Futurist or something about sort of the
new emerging paradigm in cosmology and this,
as you know, the big challenge in physics is
to reconcile general relativity and quantum
mechanics and there's a lot of theories about
string theory and all this stuff which I read
about, I do not pretend to understand it all,
but there's this new paradigm coming out around
quantum entanglement and the idea that there
really is no multiplicity of reality, it is
all one, it is all one and everything that we
experience is this fragmentary apprehension
of what is actually just one thing and it's kind of like this is what the mind does in
order to make the universe comprehensible to us, but entirely a construction of our
minds which in another context I've been arguing
for this for years that we live in this reality
hallucination, I like to call it, now the neuroscientists they call it the default
bone network, but it's the same kind of idea
that you know we don't live in reality itself,
we live in this model of reality that our brains
construct in order to make it comprehensible
because of and a lot of what that hallucination
is or that construct is it's composed of filters,
it's basically defined by what it doesn't allow in and there's neural gating, I mean
the term in neuroscience is neural gating, not a lot gets through, enough gets through
that we can construct this reality that we inhabit that we call consensus reality and
you know part of the fascination and probably
the therapeutic utility of psychedelics is
that they temporarily disable that thing, they blow it up, they blow up this default
bone network and like a computer system I think it's very similar to rebooting your
computer because it will fall back together,
the systems tend toward equilibrium and even
though you've blown it up completely and you're
in this place where you're not really in these
boundaries anymore, but it will come back
together, if it doesn't you know then you've
got a problem and that rarely happens, it usually comes back together and it usually
works better afterwards just like you know my Mac gets all messed up and I restart it
and suddenly it runs smoothly for a while until
it decides not to and I think that you know that
ability to sort of disrupt this default mode
network is at the root of a lot of the therapeutic
uses of psychedelics, that's one reason why the psychedelics can be thought of as a you
know in a way a broad spectrum psychotherapeutic
you know, they have applications to so many
different kinds of disorders from anxiety and depression to trauma and addiction and
all of these things, but it's because it opens
up an opportunity to sort of restructure your
default mode network and that's the common basis
like a broad spectrum antibiotic. I know from
reading your autobiography that before you even
began to take a serious scientific interest in
psychedelics, even as a high school student you
were widely imbibing LSD and other drugs. I didn't
start out that early, I started out in college,
but I can say I took over a hundred instances of
psychedelic use and I think they were very
beneficial for me. What I really want to get
at here, Dennis, is that in your book you talk
about an important turning point in your life.
You refer to it as the experience that took place
at La Chorrera in Colombia. I think it would be
very enlightening for our viewers to probe that experience more deeply with you.
Right. Well, yeah, the experiment at La
Chorrera is like, you know, it's part of the
Denny and Terrence mythopoetic story and you
went right to it, Jeffrey. That's the one thing I
hate to talk about because for one thing I've
talked about it a lot and for another thing it's
hard for me to even make any sense of it. This is like 50 years later. In some ways,
yeah, we went to La Chorrera in 1971 and the reason
that we went there is because we were both taking
psychedelics. Terrence was in Berkeley, I was
in Boulder, but we were exchanging, you know,
regular correspondence. They didn't have text
or email on those days, of course, but we had
this shared fascination with DMT, you know, and we
thought that DMT was really an order of magnitude
stranger than and more interesting than LSD
or other psychedelics. And back in those days,
what there basically was was LSD. Occasionally
you could get, you know, mescaline or peyote.
DMT was a rare creature, almost a unicorn level
creature at that time. There wasn't much of it,
but Terrence was very good at working the matrix
and he had it and we had experienced it and we
thought, you know, yeah, this is like the ultimate metaphysical reality, you know,
in some ways. This is just much stranger than LSD or any psychedelic and we
sort of came to it from the standpoint of science fiction in some ways. We were
both heavily influenced by science fiction and we
were, you know, so these DMT experiences seem to
us like visits to literally another place,
another dimension. You know, we framed it in
that those terms rather than like participate.
They weren't spiritual. We didn't view it that
way. They weren't like participating in in in
ethno-medical traditions or anything like that.
We had this idea that it let you penetrate
to another place and where that was in space
or time was a question. But anyway, I noticed in
your book, there was a very brief mention right
before the section on the La Chorrera experience,
you mentioned in passing the idea of being in contact
with manted like beings in a UFO and I wonder if
there's any more to that. Well, I think that was
just one of the tropes that sort of was part of
this idea of the encounter that we had. I think,
I mean, we in this encounter with the mushrooms
over, you know, 10 days or so that led up to
this experiment. I mean, we had the idea, we even
called it the teacher, you know, and I think that
we thought the teacher was channeling through the
mushrooms. It wasn't the mushrooms, it was the
teacher and the teacher, yeah, sort of had this
manted like character and so on. So that was
that was it. Lately, thinking back on our on the
conference that Anton organized, I am reading
currently this book called The Falling Sky. Have
you read that? No, I haven't. Relevant to the idea
of the DMT entities, you know, because, you
know, the question that we started out with,
is this real? Yeah. Well, this is a, this is
written by Bruce Albert, who's an anthropologist,
but he's basically translating the words of
Yanomami Shaman, Dabi Kapanua, Kapanawa, I think.
And, and he, and it's, it's, I mean, you talk about the DMT entities, for him,
they are totally real, you know, and not only,
and they get to it through the snuff. I mean,
the snuff is understood to be the food of the spirits, which he calls the zapuri.
And the shamans form essentially these symbiotic
relationships with the zapuri through the use of
this snuff. And then through the zapuri, there's
a whole other dimension of other kinds of spirits,
some ancestral, some animal, and so on. Just an
absolutely fascinating book, you know, and, and
and, and for not everybody in the tribe, but for the shamans in the tribe,
you know, the experience of the zapuri is
completely a real thing and everyday reality.
And because they're so influential, shamans
are, I mean, many, many of the men in the tribe,
you know, take this snuff, share this reality.
I highly recommend it. It's really, really,
very interesting. And for me, it, it sort of answers
the question, you know, one of the questions,
anyway, that came up in the conference, one of the things I was wondering is, you know,
and I think I asked in the, in our talk, you know,
it doesn't matter if the spirits are real or not,
what matters is the information is the information
useful or valid. And this, this book reading this
book shows that at least in this culture for these
people, the information is valid. It's what they
view, their whole worldview is seen through this
lens. And, you know, the zapuri world is as real
as the Amazonian environment that they inhabit.
So, highly recommend it. It's a long read. It's
not an easy read, but it's worth it if you're
interested. Very good. I'll take a look at it.
So, it was this fascination that DMT that led
us to go to South America in search of this
orally active form of DMT. And the reason we were
interested in that is because one thing about DMT,
many things about DMT, but one thing about it,
when you smoke it, which is how it has to be
taken, because it's not orally active, they smoke
the free base literally in a, in a crack pipe,
you get an overwhelming astonishing experience,
but it only lasts about 20 minutes, you know,
and by the time you're there and sort of wondering,
you know, what the hell is going on, you're
already on the way down, you know, and so you
don't have any time to spend in this, in this
dimension that we thought of it. So, we heard
about this, this paper that Schultes had published,
the famous R.E. Schultes in the Botanical Museum
Leads. We were thinking if you could find an
orally active form of DMT, it would last longer.
It was simply that naive that we could, it would
last longer and we could spend more time there
and we could sort of look around and see what
was going on, because by the time you sort of,
and you get deep into that space, it's already
fading, you know, by the time you've overcome your
initial astonishment. And so, we thought, well,
yeah, we have to go investigate this thing. And this was 1970, and 1971 we went there,
but a couple of, we'd heard about it about a
year before that, and we decided, and, you know,
at the time the pharmacology of ayahuasca was
not really understood, the importance of the
admixture plants, because ayahuasca is effectively
an orally active form of DMT, right? It's
potentiated by the beta carbolines, the
monoaminoxidase inhibitors in the vine, one of the
components, and that enables DMT to become orally
active. We didn't know that. Nobody knew that
at that time. There were people speculating,
but it was not clear. But then this article by
Schultes came along and it was like Varola
as an orally active hallucinogen. And for us,
it may as well have been written in neon flashing
letters, you know, with a ha, this is it. This is
the secret, and we have to go after this thing.
So, we went to La Chorrera. It was an obscure
drug that was used by the Witoto people, and
it was made from Varola, which is a tree,
widely used in the Amazon basin in the preparation of snuffs. The sap of the tree
is very high in DMT and often phymethoxy DMT
in combination. So, they prepare a snuff from
this sap, and they powder that down, and they
use it that way. And we may circle back on this,
because there's been interesting new information
about these snuffs based on this book I've been
reading, but I don't want to get ahead of myself.
So, this was different because it was orally
active, right? The other tribes use the snuff.
The Witoto use this orally active paste that they
make into little pills, and they take it that
way. And it was said to be very rapid and very
reality-disrupting, and a way to get in touch with
the little people, you know, as they called them.
And, of course, Terrence, at least, was very
interested in the little people because of the
whole machine elf thing, which I don't think
everybody sees. So, we determined to go to
South America, La Chorrera, the ancestral home of the Witotos, to look for this drug.
Well, when we got to La Chorrera, we had been cautioned on the way in. We had met
an anthropologist on the way in who was studying
the Witoto. We knew he was there. I mean, we talked
to his colleagues in Bogota. We knew at some point
our paths would cross, and they did. And he was
there. And he was at the village downriver from
La Chorrera at that time. And he was appalled,
you know, when we showed up. I mean, you can't
exactly send a text and say we're on the way.
So, these, you know, we were far more colorful
than any of the Witoto people. We were full,
hippie, mowed, you know, long beards, bells,
beads, the whole thing, you know. And it's like,
who the hell are these people? And if it wasn't bad enough, then we said, well,
hey, Doc, we're here to find Ukuhay. What can
you tell us about it? That really got him off.
And he said, you know, you can't just go start
talking to these people about Ukuhay. This is like,
you know, their biggest shamanic secrets, you know.
They'll probably kill you if you even mention it.
Well, he was a little bit, he overstated it a little bit, but we said, yeah, okay,
we'll be careful. And we went on from that
village, and we went a four-day trek to La Chorrera
Overland, which was on a parallel river, the
Garaparana. When we ended up at La Chorrera,
finally, it was a pretty rough slog, even though
it was only four or five days. But, you know,
we were very, even hardly experienced jungle
travelers. But when we showed up at La Chorrera,
we thought, well, we'll just hang out and try to
make contact discreetly and gently with the local
folks and ask them about Ukuhay. But what we
found was that about 200 acres around this mission
village, it was a Cappuccine mission, La Chorrera,
they cleared the forest and they brought in these
Cebu Cattle and the White Humpback Cattle.
And it was the rainy season. So out of every
cow pie, we're growing huge clusters of psilocybin cubensis, you know, beautiful
specimens of psilocybin cubensis, the pantropical
psilocybin mushroom. And we knew what they were.
We had very little experience with them. In fact, only one very sort of cursory
encounter, which we had at one of our stops on
the way at another town on the Putumayo on our way
to La Chorrera. And we found one or two, but it
was dry and we didn't find any specimens. So it
wasn't much of an encounter. And so when we got
to La Chorrera, we thought, oh, this is great,
you know, we can just experience these, we can
play around with these until the real secret
shows up. And we did think of this Ukuhay as the
secret, you know, we sort of created this whole
myth around the idea. Well, and so we started
eating the mushrooms on a very casual basis,
not really with the respect or the clarity that we should have. Well, the mushrooms
sort of quickly corrected that. And, you know,
we started eating them and they made it clear
that, you know, they were the real secret and
they were what we had come for. They were the
source of the knowledge that we were seeking.
And we, so that's what got us sucked into
the experiment at La Chorrera. It started, you
know, sort of laying out the framework for an
experiment, which was an experiment only in the,
in the loosest sense. It wasn't an experiment.
We thought of it that way, but not really. It
should be called the ritual at La Chorrera.
But anyway, it's, it was a, it was a, like a
telepathic download of Gnosis about what we could
do with, with these mushrooms, if we could use
them and there to imitate a sound inside our heads.
And when you imitated this sound, there was a whole elaborate thing about the molecular
resonances that this would set up and affect
the binding of the molecules into the neurons.
And would create a, a standing waveform, which
would be a reflection of a, basically some kind of
instantiation of the Akashic records, you know,
that was locked into our DNA that was locked,
in fact, into the DNA of all species. And we would have access to this. And it was a,
it was an experiment that would result in the
creation of an artifact. That would be a fusion
of matter and mind. You would be able to see it
and be it at the same time. And you could control
it with your thought, right? And so this is what we
set out to create with the experiment at La Chorrera.
Now, I have to say, you know, 50 years on, or more
than 50 years on now, this was bunk, you know,
I mean, this was, this was just a serious delusion.
You know, there's no scientific validity to this.
But we were, we were utterly convinced that,
you know, we were getting this Gnosis. And if we
got, if we did what it said, we could create
this object, and that would change everything.
You know, it would essentially bring history to
an end. And that didn't happen. We're still here,
you know. But what did happen is that we had a, what you might call a simultaneous
what you might call a simultaneous break with
reality with, you know, in psychology, as you
know, there's, there's a phenomenon called the fully ado that the folly of two.
And my brother and I experienced that in like
complementary ways, we experienced about a two
week extended alter state in which I basically
disengaged from reality completely. And my brother
became hypervigilant and totally focused on reality
and focused especially on me because I think,
you know, he was concerned about looking after
me, he didn't sleep for two weeks. And I didn't
sleep. I don't know if I slept or not. I was
not concerned with those sorts of things. I was
cruising literally through the cosmos. I experienced
this, this state of mind where I thought I had
blown up my consciousness to be co-controllance
with the edges of the universe. You know, I was
talking about being all one, I was all one with
the galaxies with the, with the, you know, with
the universe. And then slowly over this two weeks,
I began to collapse back and each 24 hours was
another step in this process. So that, you know,
first it was the universe and then it was the
super cluster and then the local cluster, then the
galaxy and so on. Eventually I condensed back into
my body and my mind, you know, and I mean severely
shaken, obviously. But, you know, in reflecting
back on this, you know, I have thought, and
I've even given talks about called, you know,
Experiment at La Churera. Is it a psychotic break?
Was it a shamanic initiation or was it an alien
encounter? And I think there are elements of all
of those things in what happened to us, you know,
and it was an inflection point, certainly in our
lives. It's like, I was 20 when this happened.
Terrence was 24. So we were just astonishingly
young when these things went down and we were,
we were at that place where young men, well
probably young women too, but young men often
get to a place where they think they know everything and they actually know nothing,
but they don't know that they know nothing. And so, you know, this was a very impactful
experience and it kind of colored the rest of our
lives. You know, my reaction to this after we did
more or less get stuck back together and could
operate in what people call consensus reality.
My reaction to that, the process of integration,
was I wanted nothing to do with it in some ways.
I wanted, I was happy to get my feet back on the ground and I sort of said, well,
you know, I'm going to go back to school
and I'm going to start studying hard science
because we'd had this conversation about, Terrence
was like, science will never explain this,
you know, and I was saying, well, we're not scientists yet. We may have thought we were
scientists, but we're not scientists. So we have to be able to do science before we can
reject science. And so I said, I'm going to go
back and study science. And that's what I did.
And then that sort of was the beginning of my
career and ethno botany, ethno pharmacology,
neuroscience and all that. Terrence went a different direction. I mean, he was
more convinced at the time that we really had done something, that we had succeeded,
what we had predicted didn't happen. But out of his ideations during this period,
what came out initially was sort of the kernel
of his ideas about time that eventually he
developed over decades into this idea of time
wave zero, which he claimed was, you know, I mean,
it was based on the on the each thing, the
mathematical sequence of each. He claimed that
it was a map of the aggression of novelty into space, time into existence, you know,
related very clearly to the philosophies of
Whitehead, although we didn't we discovered Whitehead
some years later, a couple of years later in our efforts to sort all this stuff out.
And he constructed this very elaborate idea about the time wave and that this
this described the texture of time and the aggression of novelty, and very much a sort
of I think a reflection of the fact that we were
both Catholic, you know, we grew up Catholic,
and there was this Catholicism and Christianity
in general is basically an apocalyptic religion,
I mean, built into the idea is there's going to
be an end to time. And, you know, time will end,
and then it will be the last judgment or whatever. And this was, you know, probably.
So the time wave for Terrence became like a years long effort to nail down.
When is it going to end? Where do you put the end date of this time wave? And, well,
eventually, he settled on December 21, 2012,
as the end date, for various reasons, not least
that that was a major point in the in the Aztec
calendar and the Mayan calendar, the end of the
13th back tune, which was misinterpreted as being
that the end of the whole thing, it's not really
but it was the end of a big cycle. And of course,
so it was kind of became that, well, you know,
if the singularity is going to happen, it's going
to all collapse. It's a spiral, right? It's a
fractal thing. And these cycles are getting shorter
and shorter and shorter. And finally, we'll reach
a point where they're nanoseconds. And at that
point, the singularity is going to collapse. And
it'll all go away, you know. Well, obviously,
that didn't happen, you know, and Terrence
never lived to see that, you know, the theory was
invalidated. But a lot of people took this time
wave thing very seriously, I was always a skeptic.
But a lot of people did take it seriously. And I
think it's an interesting mathematical construct,
based on the I Ching. One thing it is for sure,
at least you can interpret it this way,
it's a very, it's a 13 month lunar calendar,
which might be a way of looking at the I Ching
that nobody had really thought of. And if he had
written about it in that respect, you know, a few
sinologists would have taken note and nobody else
would have noticed, but no, he made a career out
of it. And, you know, in part, we argued a lot
about the time wave, you know, and I was saying,
you know, the problem with the time wave, there's
two problems, there's many problems with it. But
two major problems that I see with the time wave is
you, Terrence, you're the only one that can
actually interpret it. You know, it's a reflection
of your understanding of history. You know, that's a big problem. And, and the second
major problem is you haven't defined any way to
disprove it, you know, you're not interested in
disproving it. But if you want to call it theory,
you have to define what will invalidate it. And
I'm coming at that, but now for kind of from my,
you know, my scientific bias, understanding of
understanding of what science is, which I had
acquired after coming back and actually became
a scientist. I, we, you know, half of my
undergraduate study was philosophy of science,
a lot of Whitehead and other people. But one
thing about science, one thing that's beautiful
about science is you construct models, you
construct hypotheses about phenomena, something
understanding of something, and then you really
try hard to demolish that, to say, what does it
not explain? You know, what is missing here? How
does it need to be modified? Or maybe you just
trash it and start over. And, and Terrence
wasn't interested, nor could he say what was,
what would invalidate it. So, I've been talking a lot here.
Okay, it's a wonderful story, actually. There's
so many directions we could go. I know I first
learned about the time wave theory from another
student of psychedelics, Jean Euston, who was
something of a mentor of mine, and she was
enthusiastic about it. One of the points she
made was that, in our present era, we are
something of a recapitulation of what happened
to ancient Rome. You could say a fractal pattern
of the Roman Empire, and we could understand
our present era by thinking about the issues that the ancient Romans faced.
Right, right. Yeah, that was the whole idea about
the construction of the time wave, was that there
are these many cycles that were nested. It was a
fractal, it was really a fractal thing, and the
idea was that different eras in history resonate
with each other in terms of, you know, so the
4,800 year cycle reflects the shorter, I forget
what the exact spans were, but you can see these
same patterns in these different cycles, and
it's a fascinating idea. But the problem is,
the only person defining those correspondences
was Terrence. In some ways, the time wave tells
you more about Terrence's understanding of history
than it does about time. It doesn't describe time,
it describes his understanding of history, which
was not trivial, you know, he was very widespread,
it was very complex, but it was about his
own understanding of history, and we used to,
you know, we used to have, I wouldn't call them
arguments, but I call them lively discussions
about what is novelty, you know, it's supposed to
describe novelty, and I'm down with that theory.
I believe Whitehead was correct that, you know,
every day something happens that has never happened
before in the history of the universe, you know,
there is truly novel events, but what is novelty,
and how do you know it when you see it, you know,
and Terrence's, he was preoccupied, or he was
saying, well, events like, you know, the first
detonation of the atomic bomb, or the first
landing on the moon, or these incredibly
significant historical events, those are novel
events, and so he was like a proponent of the
eruptive theory of novelty, you know, it just
happens, it just explodes into history, but look
at all the precursors that lead to that, you know,
the, in the case of the atomic bomb, starting
with, you know, maybe Einstein's theory, and
understanding the physics of it, and all the work
that went before developing nuclear reaction was
understanding that, all of that was the groundwork
that led eventually to the detonation of the first
bomb, you know, in Alamogordo, Mexico in the 40s,
but so where's the novelty, you know, and I was
